data.value: Compute distance between each pair of the two collections of inputs.
See Notes for common calling conventions.
-dimensional space. Inputs are converted to float type.
-dimensional space. Inputs are converted to float type.

The distance metric to use.  If a string, the distance function can be 'braycurtis', 'canberra', 'chebyshev', 'cityblock', 'correlation', 'cosine', 'dice', 'euclidean', 'hamming', 'jaccard', 'jensenshannon', 'kulsinski', 'mahalanobis', 'matching', 'minkowski', 'rogerstanimoto', 'russellrao', 'seuclidean', 'sokalmichener', 'sokalsneath', 'sqeuclidean', 'wminkowski', 'yule'.
Additional arguments should be passed as keyword arguments
: refer to each metric documentation for a list of all possible arguments.
p : scalar The p-norm to apply for Minkowski, weighted and unweighted. Default: 2.
w : ndarray The weight vector for metrics that support weights (e.g., Minkowski).
V : ndarray The variance vector for standardized Euclidean. Default: var(vstack([XA, XB]), axis=0, ddof=1)
VI : ndarray The inverse of the covariance matrix for Mahalanobis. Default: inv(cov(vstack([XA, XB].T))).T
out : ndarray The output array If not None, the distance matrix Y is stored in this array. Note: metric independent, it will become a regular keyword arg in a future scipy version
distance matrix is returned. For each
is computed and stored in the
do not have the same number of columns.

points using    Euclidean distance (2-norm) as the distance metric between the    points. The points are arranged as
-dimensional row vectors in the matrix X.

Computes the city block or Manhattan distance between the    points.
Computes the standardized Euclidean distance. The standardized    Euclidean distance between two n-vectors
V is the variance vector; V[i] is the variance computed over all    the i'th components of the points. If not passed, it is    automatically computed.
Computes the cosine distance between vectors u and v,

is the mean of the elements of vector v,    and
Computes the normalized Hamming distance, or the proportion of    those vector elements between two n-vectors

Computes the Jaccard distance between the points. Given two    vectors,
, the Jaccard distance is the    proportion of those elements
that    disagree where at least one of them is non-zero.
Computes the Chebyshev distance between the points. The    Chebyshev distance between two n-vectors

Computes the distance between all pairs of vectors in X    using the user supplied 2-arity function f. For example,    Euclidean distance between the vectors could be computed    as follows::

_lines._line: dm = cdist(XA, XB, lambda u, v: np.sqrt(((u-v)**2).sum()))
